Find out more and post your questions here, and they'll get back to you: http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2014/11/05/critical-illness-and-life-insurance-q-amp-a-post-your-questions-for-our-experts-here.aspx

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, This is just a quick note to let you know that we've just published the transcript of last week's breast cancer webchat. You can read it here. Best wishes, Priscilla Macmillan Community Team
Posts.Title: Breast cancer webchat

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I've already asked once to stop adding comments to this thread. I don't wish to delete the original posts, but can you please continue either in the Atheists Group or the Prayer Support Group, as appropriate for you. This Community is primarily a place for cancer support, and religious debates can only cause a negative atmosphere and get in the way of the main purpose of the site. We are perfectly happy for you to discuss these topics, but please respect others by doing so in the appropriate groups where you won't upset those that have different views. Any more comments added below this one will be removed.
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I think Joycee is right here - the best place to have this discussion is over in the Atheists group. Our Community Guidelines require that you respect other people. It's fine to express the fact that it upsets you when people impose their religion on you, but we can't let that spill over into attacking people's faith. I've therefore taken out some parts of this thread that were offending some people. Those of you who do have religious faith, you may be interested in the Prayer Support group on the Community. Rather than adding any more comments to this thread, can you use the group that is relevant to you, in order to avoid upsetting those who are in the other group? Thanks. Priscilla
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I've already asked once to stop adding comments to this thread. I don't wish to delete the original posts, but can you please go either to the Atheists Group or the Prayer Support Group, as appropriate for you. This Community is primarily a place for cancer support, and religious debates can only cause a negative atmosphere and get in the way of the main purpose of the site. We are perfectly happy for you to discuss these topics, but please respect others by doing so in the appropriate groups where you won't upset those that have different views. Any more comments added below this one will be removed.
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Hi Kev, We certainly don't think that it's wrong for people to express the fact that religion is not helpful to them and I didn't mean to give that impression. I hope that I can answer your points: 1. We are not trying to single out non-believers by asking them to post in the atheists group, as we have also pointed believers to the prayer group. That way, each has a space to express their views without upsetting the others. 2. Giving either group the chance to 'convert' the other to their point of view is very much not the point of this Community, nor do I think that anyone in this thread set out to do so. I strongly disagree that most atheists would think they 'might as well not bother' expressing their views to other atheists, and likewise with religious people. The point of the initial post was for atheists to discuss how to deal with religious people who they felt were imposing their views on them. It therefore makes perfect sense for them to have that discussion in the relevant group. There may be other places on the internet that are appropriate for atheists and believers to debate their positions with, but this Community is primarily a place for cancer support and arguments detract from that.
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Hi Gill, I just wanted to jump into this thread to say thank you so much for wanting to fundraise for Macmillan - our fundraisers do really important work to help us support people affected by cancer. Making your own soap sounds like a great idea and quite unusual. We have a group here on the site called We Give Our Time - it's for anyone who supports Macmillan by fundraising, volunteering or in other ways, to get together and share ideas. You might find it helpful to join and post in there. Good luck with your fundraising!
Posts.Title: Fundraising

Posts.Content: To post a photo, when you are creating a post, use the little icon that looks like a picture of a tree (fourth from the right at the top of the box you type in).
Posts.Title: Macmillan coffee morning - £670.50!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jellies, I hope you don't mind me jumping into this thread but I've checked your account and you aren't a member of the breast cancer group (or any groups on the Community). You can reply to discussions without joining the group, but you'll need to be a member to start your own discussion. Can you see the join button at the top of this page? It should be under the group title and description. Here's a picture to show you where to look: I hope this helps. If you have any problems using the site, you can always drop us in the admin team a line on community@macmillan.org.uk. Take care, Priscilla
Posts.Title: Why You Shouldn't Google - 10 Cancer Myths Debunked

Posts.Content: Hi Lelly, Welcome to the Online Community. I'm so sorry to hear about your twin's diagnosis. It sounds as though you are really close, and it's great that you want to give her as much support as possible. You are very welcome to post here in the breast cancer group - it's a really good place to get information about other people's experiences of breast cancer and treatment. You might also find it helpful to join and post in our family and friends group - there are lots of members there whose loved ones have cancer, so it's a really good place to get support with questions about how to support your sister and how to cope yourself. I hope this helps. If you have any more questions about using the community, you can drop me and my team an email on community@macmillan.org.uk.
Posts.Title: Am I allowed to join - or would you prefer this group to be just patients...

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about this - if anyone is having any problems like this, please do email us on community@macmillan.org.uk and we can ask our technical team to investigate.

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I thought you some of you might be interested in joining in with our live Breast Cancer webchat tomorrow with Ellen, a specialist nurse from the Macmillan Support Line. It's from 12-1pm in the chatroom here: http://community.macmillan.org.uk/CuteSoft_Client/CuteChat/Channel.aspx?Place=Lobby-4

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat, I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis. I can see that the operation must be a very scary prospect, particularly if you feel that you don't have control over the decision.  I think you've had some great responses from other Community members, and I really hope it has helped to read about their experiences. It might also help you to have a look at our web page about alternative therapies.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine, I'm glad that to hear our community has been helpful to you and I hope that someone gets back to you about your query. I can't answer your question about your symptoms myself, but I just wanted to mention, if you can't find any community members who've experienced this, you could also try our Macmillan Support Line. They have specialist nurses available who can help with your medical questions. It's freephone 0808 808 00 00 and it's open Mon-Fri, 9am-8pm.

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Just to let you know that it's Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and we're hosting a webchat with specialist nurses Josie and Ellen here on the Community next week. You can come into our chatroom and post a question on Wednesday 9 October, 12-1pm. Here's the link, but don't post your question now, as the nurses won't be there until the allocated time slot: http://community.macmillan.org.uk/CuteSoft_Client/CuteChat/Channel.aspx?Place=Lobby-4 If you can't make it and you'd like to post an advance question, head over to this blog post: http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2013/10/01/breast-cancer-webchat-wednesday-9-october.aspx Priscilla

Posts.Content: Hi Tej, Sorry to hear you're having problems downloading the app. There is an iPhone version and an Android version. The Android version of the app should work on any Android phone. Can you send us an email to community@macmillan.org.uk with the make and model of your phone and what version of Android you are using? Then I will ask the team that worked on the app to look into this for you. Priscilla
Posts.Title: schedule app

Posts.Content: Hi Noodles, They are talking about the My Organiser app, which helps people keep track of treatment, appointments and medications. The mobile-friendly version of the Online Community can be found at http://m.macmillan.org.uk/community but it is a test version, and doesn't have all the features of the desktop site yet. Priscilla

For full details, or to post an advance question if you can't make it, check out our blog post: http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/02/02/hair-make-up-and-skincare-webchat-thursday-5-february.aspx
